Sunday, May 26, 1935.
Dear
Babs:
I am on the way
from Chungking
to Hankow
after a most strenuous
party in Szechuen
which it was
quite impossible
to write and
if I had written the letter
just have waited to
come along with us
on this plene.
You will
that we arrived in Chungking last
Monday and that I did not know what we
would do after
got there,
However we learned
that Chiang Kai-shek was planning to leave Yunnan-fu
right away
for Kweiyang and
would arrive Chungking on Thursday so we
stayed in Chungking for
an appointment there on Friday.
Jones and
Chevalier went over to Chengtu.
at Chungking•
We were
booked solid for
breakfast,
Forbes and I remained
tiffin and dinner with
meetings in between.
mostly long con-
on possible industrial rairo projecte in saehuen Province.
Friday afternoon Rogers and
Remer joined us
that Remer
especially was willing to fly
again with CNAC
after Broiles
dumped him
They were
both good sports in every way
and I thanked
sincerely and whole heartedly as I
small bone in his
right foot and
broke one of those short

Well we had made an appointment with the "Generalissimo" for
five o'clook Friday afternoon.
Gov, Forbes,
Rogers and I were to see him.
Forbes was
American aviation
cooperation in general, I was
Generalissimo
Rogers Military
Aviation.
storied house at the western end
of the city -
or is it the
the down
town part.
end - at any rate the section away
It is on that
long road which leads into the high
to Chengtu.
We climbed a long
flight of stone stairs
leading from the drive up to the house - soldiers all
around - soldiers
whose uniforms fit them and who wore
instead of
"sneakers".
passed they came to a real
snappy salute which we tried to acknowledge
with the easy nonchalance of those acoustoned to such deference.
door of a typically foreign house such as you would find
belonging to the
President of the First National Bank of Anywhere,
Kansas, we were ushered
into a formal parlor and presently General
Chiang and Mrs. Chiang came in.
General wore &
uniform without
any decoration
or insignia of
rank -
just as plain as K. I. Nieh's or old deacon Swann's of the First Congrega-
tional
Generalissimo"
is average height and as"Time" describes
him in their usual flippant manner, wasp-waisted.
He is 48 years old but
like most other Chinese
ten years younger.
Madam Chiang is about
typically Chinese.
Beautiful figure, very feminine with lots of
personal charm yet obviously forceful.
She has a beautiful voice and
English of so much better quality than our own that you firak
feel slightly embarrassed at your
own awkardness with your own language.
Her foice and
manner is so much like Anne Lindbergh that I couldn't help
remarking on the resemblance.
She seemed pleased
and spoke of how much
she was attrated by the Lindberghs when
they visited Nanking in 1931.
She was dressed quite simply but wore a jade ring that was probably worth
also jade
for her husband but on this occasion his personal physician Dr. Liu
She ordinarily acts as interpreter
served in her place.
Governor Forbes had his say and withdrew in my favor.

Sunday, May 26, 1935.
Dear
Babs:
I am on the way
from Chungking
to Hankow
after a most strenuous
party in Szechuen
which it was
quite impossible
to write and
if I had written the letter
just have waited to
come along with us
on this plene.
You will
that we arrived in Chungking last
Monday and that I did not know what we
would do after
got there,
However we learned
that Chiang Kai-shek was planning to leave Yunnan-fu
right away
for Kweiyang and
would arrive Chungking on Thursday so we
stayed in Chungking for
an appointment there on Friday.
Jones and
Chevalier went over to Chengtu.
at Chungking•

that Remer

again with CNAC
after Broiles
dumped him

both good sports in every way
and I thanked

Rogers and I were to see him.

American aviation
cooperation in general, I was
Generalissimo

Aviation.

be in accord with our ideas and plans.
I am qui te
sure that

eventually we shall
get some action but I have memorized Kipling's
"It is not
good for the Christian White
To hustle
the Aryan Brown
The Christian riles
And the Aryan smiles
And he weareth the
And the
end
Christian down
of the fight
Is a tombstone white
With the name of the late deceased
This Epitaph
drear
A fool lies here
Who tried
to hustle the Bast."
We planned to leave Chungking on Saturday but Chiang Kai-shek
invi ted
the whole party
for dinner
Saturday night and
requested Gov.
and Mr. Carroll
to make an inspection trip in Marshall Chang
Hsueh-liang's Boeing from Chungking to
Changsha and Nanchang,
on to Shanghai.
They are leaving Tuesday.
to catch the Taft out of Hongkong on Tuesday
Jones
and I
are trying
and we therefore decided
schedule Saturday in order
to give us one day's leeway
for bad weather
and also a day at Shanghai.
However Saturday the
weather turned very bad with low or no visability and we remained in
Chungking which proved to
be very fortunate.
Saturday morning I had
a long talk with Mr.
Donald,
now Chief advisor to Chiang Kai-shek.
Donald is an Australian who years ago organized a magazine called the
Far Bast Review.
It became very
successful.
Finally Mr.
partner sold out the controlling interest to
the Japs and the magazine
became a medium of Japanese propaganda.
gave up his interest
became an adviser
for Chang krunkkixary Tso-lin,
the old Manchurian
He has subsequently aoted in the same capacity for
Young Marshall Chang Hsueh-liang and just now is serving with
Kai-shek.
Chiang
old friend of Mr.
and the latter
that if I would go to Manila for
American Mission,
which he
Vice-Chairman and
Gov. Forbes as Chairman both urgently requested,
that he Carroll would have a long confidential talk with Donald.
Accordingly when we did
not fly I
sat in with Carroll and Donald for
a three hour talk in which we discussed the whole
commercial aviation
Donald understands and
promised to set Chiang and Madam
which is fully as important, straight on the whole subjeot.
complete menoranda with him end he told me that both Chiang
and Madam Chiang were favorably impressed with my verbal presentation.
All of us Americans are in
trouble because of
unwillingness to fly
bombs into Kweiyang•
The Italians (please
tell Col. Drysdale) did
got away without any
serious trouble.
Harry Smith who has
flown Chiang Kai-shek's Ford all
China and who even carried bombs
protest) has been dismissed so rumor has it;
Reed Knight and
Tonny Taylor,
Hangehow School
instructors,
both been dismissed
They all agreed to carry
the bombs if the
detonators were removed and
sent in another
airplane as for instance
army bomber.
detonators are in themselves highly
danger-
bombs not so bad - but
the
oute candie i eat be just too
two together
any slight
accident
bad.
we
are
involved because the
Minister
of Communications was asked to instruct
GNAC to fly the bombs
and the Minister
of
Communications without contacting the company wired
back that Pilot Nelson would do so.
Of course when Bond and I refused
to order
or even ask Nelson to fly bombs the M. of C. lost face and
that is of ecurse most
unfortunate.
Later we had a talk with M.Y. Tang
and as a result Bond and I notified the M..
of C. that we would both
fly
to
to
Chungking for a talk with Nelson,
If then Nelson
was willing
take a leave
of absence from INAC and go to work for the
Chinese
Army on terms of pay satisfactory to him we would give him every
possible assistance in the way of mechanios service,
radio, weather
lata, etc.
This
declined - but at least we got credit for making

the offer.
Saturday night Gov. Forbes,
Mr. Carroll,
Rogers,
Remer,
Dr. Jones,
Chevalier and I
all went
to dinner with the Chiang Kai-sheks.
The dinner
was foreign
style with knives and forks -
very simple and
quite good,
except for one
vicious pink jelly salads.
present in
addition to us were Mr.
Donald,
Liu and General Chiang's
confidential
secretary.
Gov. Forbes
Chiang's right and
on her left.
Carroll sat on the General's right and I sat on
So you see we aviation men received preferred consideration
Your boy friend Chevalier
much to his apparent discomfort
sat between the non-inglish speaking Secretary and
the many-language-
knowing no-language-speaking taciturn Dr. Jones:
"Chevy" couldn't
have been more effectively
muzzled and I
suspect someone must have
off Madam Chiang to
the seating that way.
Chevalier
always insists on all members of
the Mission wearing that ridiculous
red rayon badge
every function and got furious when I refused to
on my dinner coat to
the Chiang's party.
Obviously the only
ever wearing it is for purposes of identification and
it was
out of place at a private dinner.
I urged them
all not to go looking like a delegation of
town Rotarians but
I was the only one without a badge and
caught a faint smile
of approval from Madam
After dinner something very funny happened - Gov. Forbes
General
Chiang for an autographed ploture, whereupon the General
wanted one too
quite naturally
I said that I would like
A secretary
broight a lot of pictures and the General
autographed one for
each member of the party
from Chiang
using the Chinese
characters
on our respective carâs.
the stack and he only had six pictures so he sent
upstairs for another portrait which was much better and considerably
larger - inscribed it
to me and said through Madam Chiang as inter-
preter
"Last and best."
Of course I'm glad to have it but don't know
what on earth to do with it and would rather have had a smaller one.
I wired you this moming early advising you of my plans to
to Manila and will be looking
forward to hearing whether or not
you are all oK.
Got your first letter and
one From Frances at Hankow.
Called up
the MeGleskey/s and invited myself for supper - gave them
your best - also saw the Josslyns at a cocktail party given us by the
Schillings -
Standard 011 No.
1 at Hankow.
Now approaching Shanghai•
Probably
won't write again until we start
for Hongkong tonorrow.
you that Leighton Rogers cabled New York immediately
the accident to put the brakes on the publication of any stories
about his injury.
His office eabled back "Congratulations
tarat pase of every newspaper in Amerioa stop as a publicity stunt
it was a wow exclamation point recommend more conservative methods."
Professor Remer who is a
statistician and who was making his second
flight said that there had been
four accidents on CNAC lines and he
had been in 25% of them also that 50% of his flights had ended in a
crash -
that he had been in 50% of the accidents in which no one
was killed (Geo Rummill & Broiles) •
They have both been
good sports
and that has helped me over a situation
which you can well imagine
has been a most distressing one from many angles.
Lots of love and I'll be looking forward to seeing you when
I come back.
Harold
